review_title: Working for university almost pays for itself
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant, Teaching Assistant in Vancouver, WA
pros: Your entire tuition is waived, even if you are out of state (6000 in state, 13000 out of state)
cons: The extra money they pay isn't enough to live off of by itself

pros: Ability to work on any/all projects you want
cons: Sometimes they can be unorganized.

review_title: Small Liberal Arts feel in a Large Research Focused University
pros: Small class sizes; get to know professors
cons: More focus on customers (i.e., students) than employees (i.e., faculty/staff)

pros: this is a paid grad program

pros: Beautiful location, great vibe, flexible schedule

review_title: Really fun experience as a student worker

- respect for daily life 
- friendly co-workers

pros: Diverse management and supported staff and supervisor
cons: Can be slow at times but you will always find tasks to complete

job_title: Editor-in-chief, the VanCougar in Vancouver, WA
pros:
As editor of the campus newspaper, The VanCougar, I was given the opportunity to explore and strengthen my skills as a journalist while learning first-hand how to publish a small newspaper. Wonderful people to work with. Flexible hours. Earning while learning!
The VanCougar paid for me and my staff to attend the Associated College Press and College Media conferences. Amazing networking and learning experiences.
cons:
Student wages. 
Difficult to motivate student reporters to write for the paper during mid-terms and finals, yet the paper still needed to go out on time.
Requires a large investment of time to do a good job!

pros:
Great people to work with - they are friendly and you can learn a lot from them.
Good incentives to work hard.
cons:
You'll have to learn to manage your time very well.
Not as much cooperation as you might see at other places.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: Library Circulation Assistant in Vancouver, WA
pros: Great supervisor, reasonable hours, very quiet and slow paced
cons: MUST be a student and MUST be getting financial aid and MUST be approved for work study. Not enough hours, generally.

pros: great collaboration with staff on  a one on one basis
cons: lack of tools and budget instability: there was a 75 % budget cut during my time there affecting all tools renewal and maintenance process

pros: My boss and coworkers are extremely supportive and they work with my schedule, which is a huge plus!
cons: It doesn't pay the greatest. It's good for a student, though!

pros: Work life balance was good. Was able to attend classes and go to work without having issues.
cons: Some of the upper management can be difficult.
